natural problem: Let $f_0(x)=x+|x-100|-|x+100|$, and for $n\geq 1$, let $f_n(x)=|f_{n-1}(x)|-1$. For how many values of $x$ is $f_{100}(x)=0$?
natural solution: For integers $n \ge 1$ and $k \ge 0,$ if $f_{n - 1}(x) = \pm k,$ then \[f_n(x) = |f_{n - 1}(x)| - 1 = k - 1.\]This means if $f_0(x) = \pm k,$ then $f_k(x) = 0.$ Furthermore, if $f_n(x) = 0,$ then $f_{n + 1}(x) = -1,$ and $f_{n + 2}(x) = 0.$  Hence, $f_{100}(x) = 0$ if and only if $f_0(x) = 2k$ for some integer $k,$ $-50 \le k \le 50.$

We can write \[f_0(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{cl} x + 200 & \text{if $x < -100$}, \\ -x & \text{if $-100 \le x < 100$}, \\ x - 200 & \text{if $x \ge 100$}. \end{array} \right.\][asy] unitsize(0.01 cm);

Thus, the equation $f_0(x) = \pm 100$ has two solutions, and the equation $f_0(x) = 2k$ has three solutions for $-49 \le k \le 49.$  Thus, the number of solutions to $f_{100}(x) = 0$ is $2 + 2 + 3 \cdot 99 = \boxed{301}.$

 Let $f_0(x)=x+|x-100|-|x+100|$, and for $n\geq 1$, let $f_n(x)=|f_{n-1}(x)|-1$. For how many values of $x$ is $f_{100}(x)=0$? The final Answer is 301
 ### Proof
 For integers $n \ge 1$ and $k \ge 0,$ if $f_{n - 1}(x) = \pm k,$ then \[f_n(x) = |f_{n - 1}(x)| - 1 = k - 1.\]This means if $f_0(x) = \pm k,$ then $f_k(x) = 0.$ Furthermore, if $f_n(x) = 0,$ then $f_{n + 1}(x) = -1,$ and $f_{n + 2}(x) = 0.$  Hence, $f_{100}(x) = 0$ if and only if $f_0(x) = 2k$ for some integer $k,$ $-50 \le k \le 50.$
 We can write \[f_0(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{cl} x + 200 & \text{if $x < -100$}, \\ -x & \text{if $-100 \le x < 100$}, \\ x - 200 & \text{if $x \ge 100$}. \end{array} \right.\][asy] unitsize(0.01 cm);
 draw((-400,-200)--(-100,100)--(100,-100)--(400,200)); draw((-400,0)--(400,0)); draw((0,-200)--(0,200)); label("$y = f_0(x)$", (400,200), E); label("$(-100,100)$", (-100,100), N); label("$(100,-100)$", (100,-100), S);
 [/asy]
 Thus, the equation $f_0(x) = \pm 100$ has two solutions, and the equation $f_0(x) = 2k$ has three solutions for $-49 \le k \le 49.$  Thus, the number of solutions to $f_{100}(x) = 0$ is $2 + 2 + 3 \cdot 99 = \boxed{301}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f 0 x = x + abs (x - 100) - abs (x + 100)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n x. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f n x = abs (f (n - 1) x) - 1"
shows  "card {x. f 100 x = 0} = 301"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A function $f$ is defined as follows: $f(0, x) = x + |x - 100| - |x + 100|$, and for any natural number $n \geq 1$, $f(n, x) = |f(n - 1, x)| - 1$. How many values of $x$ exist such that $f(100, x) = 0$? The answer is 301.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f 0 x = x + abs (x - 100) - abs (x + 100)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n x. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f n x = abs (f (n - 1) x) - 1"
shows  "card {x. f 100 x = 0} = 301"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Let $f_0(x)=x+|x-100|-|x+100|$, and for $n\geq 1$, let $f_n(x)=|f_{n-1}(x)|-1$. For how many values of $x$ is $f_{100}(x)=0$? The final Answer is 301
 ### Proof
 For integers $n \ge 1$ and $k \ge 0,$ if $f_{n - 1}(x) = \pm k,$ then \[f_n(x) = |f_{n - 1}(x)| - 1 = k - 1.\]This means if $f_0(x) = \pm k,$ then $f_k(x) = 0.$ Furthermore, if $f_n(x) = 0,$ then $f_{n + 1}(x) = -1,$ and $f_{n + 2}(x) = 0.$  Hence, $f_{100}(x) = 0$ if and only if $f_0(x) = 2k$ for some integer $k,$ $-50 \le k \le 50.$
 We can write \[f_0(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{cl} x + 200 & \text{if $x < -100$}, \\ -x & \text{if $-100 \le x < 100$}, \\ x - 200 & \text{if $x \ge 100$}. \end{array} \right.\][asy] unitsize(0.01 cm);
 draw((-400,-200)--(-100,100)--(100,-100)--(400,200)); draw((-400,0)--(400,0)); draw((0,-200)--(0,200)); label("$y = f_0(x)$", (400,200), E); label("$(-100,100)$", (-100,100), N); label("$(100,-100)$", (100,-100), S);
 [/asy]
 Thus, the equation $f_0(x) = \pm 100$ has two solutions, and the equation $f_0(x) = 2k$ has three solutions for $-49 \le k \le 49.$  Thus, the number of solutions to $f_{100}(x) = 0$ is $2 + 2 + 3 \cdot 99 = \boxed{301}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f 0 x = x + abs (x - 100) - abs (x + 100)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n x. n \<ge> 1 \<longrightarrow> f n x = abs (f (n - 1) x) - 1"
shows  "card {x. f 100 x = 0} = 301"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider a function $f$ with two arguments, a natural number and a real number, defined recursively as follows: $f(0, x) = x + |x - 100| - |x + 100|$ and for all natural numbers $n \geq 1$, $f(n, x) = |f(n - 1, x)| - 1$. How many real numbers $x$ are there such that $f(100, x) = 0$? The final answer is 301.
